Rich

> gu ?? .............. shi = smith/maker/worker

> ?? ?? Nanako Ji, Takabori, Kana ?? ??

> ?? ?? = red copper
kana ?? ............. ?? = color
> I have the rest as the usual NBTHK Hozon, date and seal etc..
>
> Cheers
>
> Rich

you 'll have to figure out the pronounciation

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: The box shaped kanji (looks like kuni ) is pronounced  zu and means theme . The last part reads : Shakudo nanako ji  takabori kin iro-e Best regards Danny
messages.messageBody:
The box shaped kanji (looks like kuni ) is pronounced "zu" and means theme
.

The last part reads :
"Shakudo nanako ji takabori kin iro-e"

Best regards
Danny

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: All, looking for some help with this Kodogu Kanteisho. I have most of it I think. From right to left Kanteisho One, Autumn flowers and Insects ?? Kogai. Mumei.
messages.messageBody:
All, looking for some help with this Kodogu Kanteisho. I have most of it
I think.

From right to left

Kanteisho

One, Autumn flowers and Insects ?? Kogai.

Mumei. Kyo Kanagu ??

?? ?? Nanako Ji, Takabori, Kana ?? ??

I have the rest as the usual NBTHK Hozon, date and seal etc..

Cheers

Rich

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/upload/Kogai-Papers-trans.jpg

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you for your help. Regards, David ... From: Dr John P Lissenden To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 8:48 AM Subject:
messages.messageBody:
Thank you for your help.

Regards,
David
----- Original Message -----
From: Dr John P Lissenden
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 8:48 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba mei


Dear DAvid

Kono Haruaki certainly used another kanji for 'haru', as illustrated
in Kinko Meikan pp.357a-360d and as listed in Nihon To Koza, but
Murakami Haruaki would appear to fit your requirements.

Thank you for the additional photographs - a lovely tsuba. It would
have made life too easy if the kao had been included!

Regards, John L.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@u...>
wrote:

Nihon to Koza shows a different first kanji for the signature of two
Haruaki, but this would seem to be the most likely hypothesis.
>
> Here are some more pictures. The tsuba has a hakogaki:
>
> http://zincavage.org/GravestoneandRaven.html
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: Dear DAvid Kono Haruaki certainly used another kanji for haru , as illustrated in Kinko Meikan pp.357a-360d and as listed in Nihon To Koza, but Murakami
messages.messageBody:
Dear DAvid

Kono Haruaki certainly used another kanji for 'haru', as illustrated
in Kinko Meikan pp.357a-360d and as listed in Nihon To Koza, but
Murakami Haruaki would appear to fit your requirements.

Thank you for the additional photographs - a lovely tsuba. It would
have made life too easy if the kao had been included!

Regards, John L.

wrote:

Nihon to Koza shows a different first kanji for the signature of two
Haruaki, but this would seem to be the most likely hypothesis.

>
> http://zincavage.org/GravestoneandRaven.html

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: Unfortunately, I do not presently have the Haynes on hand.  The Nihon to Koza shows a different first kanji for the signature of two Haruaki, but this would
messages.messageBody:
Unfortunately, I do not presently have the Haynes on hand. The Nihon to Koza shows a different first kanji for the signature of two Haruaki, but this would seem to be the most likely hypothesis.

Here are some more pictures. The tsuba has a hakogaki:

http://zincavage.org/GravestoneandRaven.html




----- Original Message -----
From: Dr John P Lissenden
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 4:38 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba mei


Dear David

How about Haruaki - see H 00770.0 (or, less probably, H 00771.0) in
Haynes' Index of Japanese Sword Fittings and Other Artists.

Regards, John L.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@u...>
wrote:
> http://zincavage.org/NewTsubaMei.html
>
> The closest kanji I can find are æT´ sei, ha and æ~Zmei, myo, min.
But I do not find any tsuba-makers named Seimin, Hamin, &c. in the
Nihon to Koza index, so I must be wrong?
>
>
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: tsuba mei
messages.msgSnippet: http://zincavage.org/NewTsubaMei.html The closest kanji I can find are 晴 sei, ha and 明mei, myo, min.  But I do not find any tsuba-makers named Seimin,
messages.messageBody:
http://zincavage.org/NewTsubaMei.html

The closest kanji I can find are 晴 sei, ha and 明mei, myo, min. But I do not find any tsuba-makers named Seimin, Hamin, &c. in the Nihon to Koza index, so I must be wrong?




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
